description: Check N310 can return "N310  timeutils.now() must be used instead of datetime.now()", but timeutils.now() does not exist. Only utcnow() does.
title: N310 check recommends function that doesn't exist

comments.content: Check N310 can return "N310  timeutils.now() must be used instead of datetime.now()", but timeutils.now() does not exist. Only utcnow() does.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~stanislaw-pitucha

comments.content:
This hacking was added to make it easy to override now() and utcnow() return values in tests. See bug 1200141 for more information.

To fix this bug, we should add now() function to timeutils module. But timeutils module belongs to Oslo, so this affects Oslo also.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~vsergeyev

comments.content:
I'm not sure adding .now() is needed. No code uses it at the moment. My first usage was actually a mistake too and I should've used .utcnow().
Would implementing .now() in timeutils even be accepted if there's no need for it?
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~stanislaw-pitucha

comments.content: Isn't the right fix to change the message emitted by hacking?

comments.content: This rule is in nova not oslo or hacking: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/nova/tree/nova/hacking/checks.py#n40

comments.content: Thanks, Joe. I don't think this is an Oslo issue, if the message in the nova check is just giving the wrong instructions.
